newsitem.title: FRANCE: Armaments workers protest in Paris.
newsitem.headline: Armaments workers protest in Paris.

text.p: Up to 25,000 workers from France's state-owned armaments industries staged a noisy but peaceful march through central Paris on Saturday to protest against government plans to close factories, organisers said.
Police said the number of marchers was less than half that claimed by march organisers.

The protesters, many of whom belong to the Communist-led CGT metals workers union, marched under a forest of flags and coloured balloons, throwing firecrackers and chanting slogans against Defence Minister Charles Millon.
The plant closures are part of a wide-ranging overhaul of France's defence policies which include a reduction in forces.
Shrinking international arms budgets also mean less clients are expected in coming years for France's defence industries, among the largest in the world.
A recent parliamentary report estimated that up to 70,000 jobs out of a total 280,000 could be lost in the next six years.
The defence ministry said some 9,000 jobs would be lost in 1996-1997 but most would involve not replacing workers when they retired.
Many of the workers who came to Paris were from the Atlantic or Channel ports of Brest, Lorient and Cherbourg where naval yards are particularly badly hit.
